Description: Six fragments of papyrus with demotic text on recto and verso, arranged in columns. The largest fragment (fragment 6: bottom of the frame) is torn on both sides and at the top but preserves the bottom margin. It has the lower part of three columns of text on both recto and verso (trace of a fourth column on the recto). Column 1 has x+12 lines of text; column 2 x+5; column 3 x+4. The other fragments have parts of up to 6 lines of texts, often very faded. The fragments appear to be written in the same hand (or at least very similar hands). Palimpsest.
Curator's comments: Previously unregistered; acquisition and provenance unknown. One of a group of demotic papyri mounted between sheets of perspex (76273-87). A series of names and numbers, including fractions of an aroura, suggests that these fragments belong to an administrative document or an account dealing, at least in part, with land measurement. Other papyri in this group, on the basis of internal evidence, can be assigned to Herakleopolis. To be published by C.J. Martin
Condition: Papyrus Survey: Condition Details: Papyrus: displaced fragments, frayed, loss, insect attack, fragile, degraded Black ink (smudged, palimpsest) Mount Details: Sandwich:glass Binding: Filmoplast T self adhesive linen tape Object Priority: A Mount Priority: A Overall Condition: C Curatorial condition comment: fair (incomplete)
